missionPrompt: Generate ONE Elite-Level Standalone NGN Item.
specifications: TAB SYNC: Populated EHR subsections in 'itemContext' (SBAR, Labs, Vitals, Radiology, MAR) MUST sync with the item stem.
SBAR: Exactly 120-160 words, military time (HH:mm), SBAR format.
SCORING RULES: SATA/Highlight: Polytomous (+/- 1.0 penalty). Matrix/Cloze: 0/1 (no penalty). Bowtie: Linked Dyad/Triad scoring.
RATIONALE: Deep clinical/pathophysiological explanations. No 'Opt X is wrong' generic filler.

itemContext.SBAR: 18:00, Dr. Smith, this is Nurse Jones on the surgical unit. I'm calling about Mr. David Lee, post-op right tibia ORIF, room 302. He reports severe pain in his right lower leg, rated 9/10, despite hydromorphone 2mg IV at 17:00. Dressing is dry/intact, but right calf is tense/swollen. Pulses are present but diminished compared to the left leg. He's increasingly anxious/agitated. Vitals at 17:30: BP 140/90, HR 110, RR 24, SpO2 97% on 2L NC. I'm concerned about possible compartment syndrome. Recommend immediate assessment and possible fasciotomy. I'll continue to monitor vitals and neurovascular status closely and administer oxygen as needed.

Radiology.X-Ray Right Tibia/Fibula (14:00): Post-operative, hardware in place. No acute fractures noted.

stem: Mr. Lee, post-op right tibia ORIF, is at risk for acute compartment syndrome. Based on the assessment findings and provided data, select the FOUR (4) most appropriate nursing interventions to include in the patient's plan of care.

options.text: Elevate the right leg above heart level.
options.rationale: Elevating the leg above heart level decreases arterial perfusion, worsening ischemia. In compartment syndrome, maintaining arterial blood flow is crucial; elevation is contraindicated.

options.text: Maintain the right leg at heart level.
options.rationale: Maintaining the leg at heart level promotes arterial blood flow to the extremity. This is crucial in the setting of potential ischemia from compartment syndrome, ensuring adequate oxygen delivery to the tissues.

options.text: Apply ice packs to the right calf.
options.rationale: Applying ice causes vasoconstriction, further reducing blood flow to the affected compartment. This exacerbates ischemia and is contraindicated in compartment syndrome, potentially worsening tissue damage.

options.text: Assess and document the patient's pain level frequently.
options.rationale: Frequent pain assessment is crucial. Unrelieved or escalating pain, especially with passive movement, is a key indicator of compartment syndrome. Documentation helps track trends and the effectiveness of interventions, guiding further management.

options.text: Loosen constrictive dressings or casts as prescribed.
options.rationale: Constrictive dressings or casts exacerbate the pressure within the compartment. Loosening them, as prescribed, alleviates external compression and improves circulation. The provider needs to be notified for dressing adjustments to prevent further complications.

options.text: Encourage active range of motion exercises of the right foot and ankle.
options.rationale: Active ROM exercises increase pressure within the compartment, exacerbating the condition. Passive range of motion may be attempted cautiously by the provider, but active exercises are contraindicated due to the risk of increased pressure and pain.

options.text: Monitor peripheral pulses, capillary refill, and sensation of the right leg.
options.rationale: Neurovascular assessment is paramount. Compartment syndrome compromises blood flow and nerve function. Changes in pulses, capillary refill, and sensation are critical indicators of ischemia and nerve damage, requiring immediate intervention.

options.text: Administer additional doses of hydromorphone as requested by the patient.
options.rationale: Escalating pain unrelieved by analgesics is a hallmark sign of compartment syndrome. Masking the pain without addressing the underlying cause delays diagnosis and treatment, potentially leading to irreversible muscle and nerve damage.

clinicalPearls: Early recognition of compartment syndrome is crucial. The '6 Ps' (Pain, Pallor, Pulselessness, Paresthesia, Paralysis, Pressure) are classic signs, although pulselessness and paralysis are late findings. Unrelieved pain, especially with passive movement, is a key early indicator. Monitor CK and myoglobin levels if compartment syndrome is suspected. Prompt intervention can prevent irreversible damage.
questionTrap: Many students incorrectly assume that elevating the limb will help, due to its effectiveness in treating edema from other causes. However, in compartment syndrome, it reduces arterial flow. Also, students may think aggressively medicating the pain is the best initial action, without considering that the pain itself is a critical symptom. Recognizing the underlying pathophysiology is key.
mnemonic: The 5 P's (Pain, Pallor, Paresthesia, Paralysis, Pulselessness) + Pressure = Possible Compartment Syndrome. Remember to keep the limb at heart level, not elevated, to maintain arterial perfusion. 'At the Heart' is where the blood needs to be!
references: Bickels, A., & Eidelman, M. (2022). Acute compartment syndrome of the leg. Clinical Orthopaedics and Related Research, 480(5), 891-903.
